reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The San Juan Inn has an unbelievable location, on a cliff above the San Juan River. The restaurant is good enough and has beer, since it is not on the Indian Reservation. We have been staying here for years, and like it much better than the over-priced rooms at Monument Valley. The rooms are nice and always updated.
reviews.title: I Love It!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: we decided to extend our stay in Mexican Hat, UT. The first night hotel would require us to move room so we called the San Juan Inn. they had an unusual option for a reasonable rate, 88 dollars. a freestanding unit just down the road from the main lodge. It was a Yurt. free standing round building with a bed and bathroom facilities, AC and a outdoor patio. The privacy was great, the view was nice but the bed was a bit small compared with what we are used to. There is no TV or Mini Fridge, or coffee maker but plenty of outlets. we watched a movie in the laptop after dark.
reviews.title: second night in town, second hotel- first Yurt

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The issues were an odd smell when we first arrived, after opening the door for a bit it aired out and was gone. the skylight was neat- a rare rain storm came through that evening and is was nice to watch from inside.
reviews.title: Great place in the Four Corners Area

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: the patio was great the next day for enjoying the morning air and writing post cards. there are a couple of restaurants and a gas station within walking distance.
reviews.title: Exceeded Expectations!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We both agreed it was a good night sleep, no neighbors slamming door, no ice machines outside of room and much better than setting up a tent in the wind and rain.
reviews.title: Very old with limited upkeep

reviews.text: Nice hotel. Very clean. They even have a place to repare motorcycles. We asked for a room downstairs and they gave us one at the far end of the motel which is normally reserved for people who have pets. It was very quite, and in front of our room was a little garden with a view of the San Juan River. The restaurant is good.
reviews.title: Quiet Place
Nice location perched overlooking the river.
reviews.text: Nice location perched overlooking the river. The room was clean and tidy, with air con and wifi. The signal on the wifi was poor and the air conditioner was a bit noisy and leaky. Apart from that, this is a nice little place to stay if visiting Monument Valley. Staff really friendly, laundry and gym on site and a pleasant outside seating area

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This was a spontaneous trip, we reserved same day. Our room was nice (the large one over the garage), quiet, and clean, with a view of the river and bluffs beyond. The best thing about the San Juan Inn is it's location. Situated on a shelf between the cliffs and the San Juan River, it's pure Southwest, with a nice riverside cafe. We visited Natural Bridges National Monument and Monument Valley on this very short trip, San Juan Inn is centrally located between the two, plus there is much, much more to see nearby.
reviews.title: nice riverside motel in the great Southwest

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I don't remember what we paid, but it was less than the $110 mentioned in a previous review (maybe we got a "last-minute" rate?). Anyway, we felt it was a good value, especially considering the remote location. After a hard day of driving/ hiking/ sightseeing, it was great just to relax, have dinner, and walk along (above) the river, right on the property.
reviews.title: Expected much more for the Price.

reviews.text: With regard to a previous reviewers remarks about the Navajo Tribal Park in Monument Valley: I can assure you the Navajo are not "ashamed" of their primitive road through the park. To the contrary, they have retained the "close-to-the-land" feel of their Valley by keeping some of the roads unpaved and unimproved. I took one of their tours in the open-top jeep/trucks years ago. They are open so as to allow you full, unobstructed views of your surroundings. It was a great Western experience - one I would recommend to all Monument Valley visitors. (And the admission fee to this spectacular Tribal Park is about the same as an admission to one of our National Monuments.) Embrace the West and it's few remaining bumpy dirt roads - think of the movie "Stagecoach"!!
reviews.title: Peace on earth at year's end

reviews.text: When you leave most of civilization behind and you find yourself here, demanding and hard-to-please travelers should move on quickly! This property is a great place for seeing Monument Valley, the interesting Mexican Hat stone and the 'bends' of the San Juan River. The hotel has small and cozy rooms and the restaurant serves a hearty serving of Navajo cooking. We spent 2 night here and enjoyed the amazing views and went back and forth through the surrounding landscapes and the tremendous natural beauty! You can buy gas and some provisions in town but don't expect to be pampered by the hard-working citizens of this tiny community! I would stay here again and feel comfortable and safe in this outpost amongst the backdrop of nature! Try to make your travels during the day, it is darker at night than you've ever experienced!
reviews.title: Not the end of the world but...

reviews.text: We spent one night at San Juan Inn while visiting the Monument Valley. We decided to stop at Mexican Hat, a very smal lvillage with just two or three motels on the San Juan river, plus a gas station and a market. And there is also a great steak house I reccomend!!! To eat great hamburgers and steaks (if you are not a vegetarian, of course!).
reviews.title: we slept in the yurta, beautiful experience

reviews.text: When I made my reservation in April, San Juan Inn asked me if I preferred to sleep in their yurtas (they have three) and are very very close to the small village. I saw them on their web site and I liked them, so I accepted. They were even better than on the web. WEe had one with a double and two single beds and another with a double. Both were very very clean, and they were in the middle of nowhere, apparently,but close to the small village that we could reach on foot. Just one thing you may dislike: there is not door to separate the bathroom, just a separé.
reviews.title: Breathtaking views....

reviews.text: The complaints about lack of TVs, vending machines and ice makers at this little inn amaze me. Don't people come to Monument Valley for the outdoors? Well, if you've come to soak up the scenery, I can highly recommend this hotel, especially their yurts. I stayed in the green one for a night in August, and what a view: sitting out on the "patio" watching the red cliffs change color at sunset was worth the price alone. The room was also clean and comfortable and featured a domed ceiling with plexiglass so you could see the stars at night. The manager was very friendly and, having lived on the reservation all his life, knows a lot about the area. He recommended a little drive I could take while waiting for my room to be ready and plotted it out on a map for me. I also loved the restaurant next door. Get the Navajo taco, and don't forget to ask for the homemade salsa!
reviews.title: "Retro Hotel Built in the 50's"

reviews.text: Stayed here one night on the way from Page to Moab. If you are looking for a 5 star hotel in Mexican Hat you are out of luck folks. But, if you are looking for a place that is the way people stayed 50 years ago , then this is the place. I look at the hotel as a novelty for what is is and was years ago. All room entrance are outside entrances with a real key. The room we were in had 2 rooms, one with a dbl and the other with a dbl and a twin bed. This is perfect of a traveling family.
reviews.title: Great Place

reviews.text: Nicely located at the San Juan river, just north of Monument Valley and south of Goosenecks Statepark, Valley of the Gods, Muley Point, etc.makes the San Juan Inn an ideal spot when visiting the area. The have quite different room types, furnished quite simple but sufficient. Some nice outdoor seating to enjoy the evening and the beautiful night sky.
reviews.title: Can't beat the location! Good accomodation at the right spot.

reviews.text: GO ONLY IF YOU WANT TO END UP BEING MISTREATED, STRANDED IN THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT WITH NO ROOM AND LIED TO. AVOID THIS PLACE!!!!
reviews.title: TERRIBLE SERVICE-DIDN'T HONOR OUR RESERVATION!!!

reviews.text: Planned our stay at this place in Jan 2011, reserved via email and by phone, got email confirmation that all OK. Called two days prior to arrival to reconfirm. They took our credit card number, ran it through that evening to reconfirm that it was valid (AmEx checked and confirmed that for us) but when we arrived they were "full, had no vacancy " and "had no record of or reservations" . They turned us away with not a single word of apology or anything. Actually the woman who was walking away from the reception area --she said her name was Cathy (Kathy) --laughed and did not offer any alternative and it was 10PM at night, we were travelling with a small child and Mexican Hat is in the middle of nowhere. A TRULY AWFUL EXPERIENCE. DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!!!!
reviews.title: OK stay!
